item.title: Henri Bergius
item.description:
Henri Bergius

Hacker and an occasional adventurer. Author of Create.js and NoFlo. Decoupling software, one piece at a time.

item.title: Silicon Valley can't stop innovating around pizza
item.description:
Silicon Valley can't stop innovating around pizza

Entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley can't sleep. You see, they have a problem on their hands, and it's circular and saucy and requires an inordinate amount of human labor to produce. That means inefficiency, which is the enemy of overwrought Medium posts everywhere.

item.title: Berlin can now usurp London as startup capital of Europe
item.description:
Berlin can now usurp London as startup capital of Europe

Startups are not the only ones digesting the shock result this weekend. As political analysts predict Germany will take a larger role as a global leader as the most powerful country in the European Union, technology observers should expect the same for the country in the entrepreneurs' realm.

item.title: Fire in Microgravity
item.description:
Fire in Microgravity

In space, flames don't extinguish under the same low-oxygen conditions that would put them out on Earth, setting the stage for dangerous flare-ups.

item.title: Solar Impulse completes Atlantic crossing with landing in Seville
item.description:
Solar Impulse completes Atlantic crossing with landing in Seville

The zero-fuel aeroplane, Solar Impulse, has touched down in Spain, completing the 70-hour Atlantic leg of its historic bid to circle the globe. The landing in Seville marked the end of the 15th stage of Solar Impulse's journey.

item.title: Google search spike suggests people don't know why they Brexited
item.description:
Google search spike suggests people don't know why they Brexited

The United Kingdom - the country of my birth - has just voted to leave the European Union. The majority of the electorate has chosen to turn its back on the biggest political project in the world, a flawed but forward-thinking union that served as the only concrete symbol of European unity after the continent was torn apart by two World Wars.

item.title: What I learned from analysing 1.65M versions of Node.js modules in NPM - Security and Node.js
item.description:
What I learned from analysing 1.65M versions of Node.js modules in NPM - Security and Node.js

So what does it take to analyse NPM and all its modules and versions? To begin with, you need data about what is in the repository. This is actually surprisingly easy, because NPM provides you with a simple way to set up your own copy of it.

item.title: AI, Apple and Google
item.description:
AI, Apple and Google

(Note - for a good introduction to the history and current state of AI, see my colleague Frank Chen's presentation here.) In the last couple of years, magic started happening in AI. Techniques started working, or started working much better, and new techniques have appeared, especially around machine learning ('ML'), and when those were applied to some long-standing and important use cases we started getting dramatically better results.

item.title: Blade Runner
item.description:
Blade Runner

After studying Alien in intimate detail, it's time to look at the typography and design of Ridley Scott's other classic sci-fi movie, Blade Runner. Based on Philip K. Dick's novel Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?, Blade Runner cements Scott's reputation for beautiful, gritty, tech noir science fiction.
